Since I have come to dispassion,

analyzed: tam bhikkhum savejetu kāmā yena saḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: and who wanted to stir up a sense of urgency in him, approached that monk and addressed him in verse:
“This water-born flower
that you’re sniffing without having been given:
This is a part of theft,
you who are called ‘Sir’.”
“I don’t steal or break into houses,
I don’t rob or commit burglary.
But for what reason
am I called ‘the one with the scent of an elephant’?
“He who digs up the roots
and breaks the lotuses,
with such a busy life,
why isn’t he called that?”
“A man who is busy with work,
smeared with mud and clay,
I have nothing to say about him,
but you deserve to be spoken to.
For the one who is free of corruptions,
who always seeks to be pure,
even the slightest evil
appears as big as a mountain.”
“Surely, spirit, you know me,
and you have compassion for me.
Again, spirit, you should speak
when you see someone like me.”
“We don’t live off you,
nor do we want to be your servants.
You yourself, monk, should know
how to go to a good destination.”
